description.text: This creates a belt pulley out of a 625 bearing.

This is a plastic wrapper which lets you make an idler pulley out of 625 bearing. The 625 bearing is a smaller, more compatible size than the 608 bearing that's usually used in Repraps, because the diameter is closer to that of the drive pulley.
This bearing guide has an inner lip on the bottom, which holds the bearing so that it's centered under the belt.
I printed it with 25% fill and 2 perimeters.  If your printer has problems with printing the upper lip, you can decrease the topangle variable. The file is set for a 6mm belt... increase the beltwidth variable if your belt is wider.
Also, since it is small, you might have problems with ABS if you print too fast. I printed it at 15mm/s.  Try to set your extruder temp as low as possible.  If the upper lip starts to curl upwards, you need to add some cooling while it's printing the first few layers. I used a fan set at a very low speed to blow on it.  If your printer vibrates a lot, you should also slow down the speed, because the accuracy has to be pretty good for it to turn out nicely.
The bearing is a tight fit, so any blobbing and other imperfections may make it hard to insert. Clean up the inside carefully with an x-acto knife if you're having trouble inserting the bearing.

description.text:
This is case.
It is made for the MKS 1.4 / 1.5 Board and 2 Mosfet for Printers like the Tevo Tarantula.
It can be printed on the small Buildplate (200x200mm), so everyone can print and use it.
For the cooling fan there are three Options ranging from 40 to 80mm.

I know the Design can be al little cramped with all the Cables, but everything fits!
The Design is well tested and working. If you have any Problems getting all your cables through the Holes, you can cut out the middle parts, to get a bigger hole.

With the Mounting Holes on the Back, and the Side, you should have enough Options to mount your case to the Frame. There are Offset Brackets included as well.

What you need:
12x Motherboard Screws 9x5mm (4 for MKS Board and Mosfets each)
4x M4x6 for the Cover
4x Screws for the Fan, depending on your Fan Size.

You can use Brass Inserts If you like.

A 4mm Drill because the Screws are a tight fit!

Update 02/23/2018
Added a 70mm Fan Cover

Update 01/06/2018
Added a 92mm Fan Cover

Update 10/16/2017
Uploaded a new STL File for the Main Body due to a 1 degree tilt in the old file. Should be fixed now.

Update 09/04/2017
I added Screw Holes at the Bottom of the Case. These are for the Stand that now comes with this Package. Thanks to stage_monkey for the Idea. If you want a Raspberry Pi 3 instead of Mosfets, check out his remix https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2516091

Update 09/03/2017
Case got a much needed Update due to a Design flaw.
The Holes for the Cables are not bridged anymore, so you don´t have to cut them.
Now it´s just print and use.

If you run in to any Problems, Please let me know.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

If you have a Layer Cooler, you won´t need Supports.

title: X Axis Motor Cable Strain Relief (Nema 17)

description.text:
Problem
Recently had a few issues with my X axis intermittently stopping in the middle of a print and also having shifted layers on the X axis. I checked the belts, motor coupling and even changed the steeper driver trying to locate the issue.

Solution
After further testing it turned out to be an intermittent loose pin on the X axis motor cable where it plugs into the motor Molex connector. This cable doesn't move that much but clearly it's enough to loosen over time, especially if you print lots of tall objects. The strain relief bracket should prevent the connector from receiving any minor stress and help reduce long term issues.

Fitting is pretty straight forward with the strain relief bracket clicking into place over the motor, if you follow the image sequence I have provided it should be clear. You may need to free up a bit more slack cable as the strain relief loop uses about 40mm of extra cable.

Additionally you could add 1 or 2 cable ties to fully lock it into place, but I don't see this as being necessary in most cases.

title: Furious FPV True-D V3 Case for Fatshark Attitude V3 Goggles
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a design for a flexible housing or cover that protects the Furious FPV V3 module when used in the Fatshark Attitude V3 FPV Goggles. It offers some impact and weather protection over running the module uncovered and adds some strain relief for the pins when carrying multiple antennae. Further, most importantly, it does not require that you modify your goggles in any way to use it.

This part should ideally be printed in a flexible filament, slightly translucent to allow the indicator LEDs to be visible -- although in testing I did get a previous version to work when using ABS. This should not require any support for printing.

author: beta_ready

description.text: Clip extension

title: Solar Filter Adapter for Camera or Telescope

description.text:
Here's my take on a solar filter adapter for my camera/telescope. The OpenScad file is also included so you can adjust to fit your lens and filter sizes.

Key variables are :
lensDiam = 78; //actual diameter of the front of the lens, maybe a little smaller even so the lens sits against the faceplate rather than the filter itself
lensHoleDiam = 88+4; // the "88" is the actual diameter of my lens body, behind the front element and the +x gives room for foam tape around the inside
lensHeight = in.5; //how tall should the lens surround tube be (.5 is bare min I think, .75 would probably be better)
filterX = in4; //width of the filter film
filterY = filterX; //assumes square filter, but change if yours isn't

I used the 4"x4" filter from Thousand Oaks Optical https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00DS7IFQS which covers my lens with some room to spare.

Print 2 separate pieces, the front face and the back. The back is designed for some foam weatherstripping tape to be added inside to hold it onto the lens. It worked, but I didn't feel it was sturdy enough and rather than enlarge the back tube and reprint, I sewed together a spandex "sock" and attached it to the ring with hot glue. The sock just slides over the lens and holds it snugly, but it's easy to remove during totality.

To assemble, just put the filter into the front and set the back on. Mine was tight enough that it just clicked together, but I wrapped the edges in thin copper tape to make sure it stayed together if it got bumped and also to help reflect back some of that solar energy rather than cooking the filter too much.

Also, I added some thin weatherstripping

title: Speaker Corner Mount - Universal Bracket for Satellite Speakers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a corner bracket for mounting a Satellite Speaker to a wall. Print in ABS, support free.

To use this you'll need one M3 Bolt (about 16 - 20 mm), an M3 nut (not nylock), two wall plugs and two screws to match. After fitting on the wall at your desired height, screw the bolt partially into the inside of the housing, slide the nut in the slit and align (it's tight but it fits), then tighten the bolt to get your desired angle on the speaker -- tight means a more vertical position, looser gives a slight down angle.

description.text:
I picked up a LOSI DBXL-E the other day, and found out that there was a major gap in the recieverbox where stones, dirt and water could enter the recieverbox.
So I decided to make a little thingy to close the gap and keep the dirt outside the box.

It is a nice tight fit, so it should keep most of the water out as well.

Just print and put in place, no modding needed :-)

I printed it in PLA and used 50% infill but it could do with less.

I also added the sketchup file in case you want to make any changes.
Please let me know if you do.

description.text:
If you need a base plate for your LEGO Technic builds ... here we go!

I did three versions of that base plate:

  • plate_orig_15x15.stl --> dimensions like original LEGO Technic beams!
  • plate_5holes_15x15.stl --> the technic holes are 5mm instead of 4.8mm ... I had better experience in the past with 5mm holes!
  • plate_5holes_norecess_15x15.stl --> the technic holes are 5mm instead of 4.8mm AND there is no recess on the underside of the plate, thus no need for support material (if you insert a Technic pin to the holes they will protrude a little bit on the underside of the plate)!

description.text: Porta Papel Higienico

I was inspired after watching Wil Wheaton's TableTop on Geek & Sundry to print out a dual extrusion D20. After searching for a while I figured out that somehow this doesn't exist. So hopefully this corrects the matter!
Luckily Whosawhatsis's simplified D20 SCAD script was incredibly easy to hack for this purpose. I was really lazy so there are two scripts to create the individual stl files. I've also blown up a "big" version, but I'd recommend the regular size due to issues with really big prints.

Download d20.stl & d20 neg.stl. For replicatorg use the "merge .slt for DualExtrusion" function under the gcode menu using these files.  Print the gcode on your replicator and enjoy!
Note that the files have a lot of corners which tend to warp during the print.  I'd recommend printing as hot as you dare in order to get good adhesion.  I had a couple tries before I was happy with it.  I also saw a lot of string deposits from the white extruder because of thermal expansion between printing numbers.  Obviously I'm still learning about how to deal with two heads.
Printed dice are not going to be correctly weighted, but it seems alright except where a corner pealed off the platform.

title: Denso Window Motor Adapater to Marvin Windows

description.text:
Our robotics team was cleaning up and we had extra Denso car window motors. I've got a Marvin Casement window in my workshop that I literally have to climb onto my (deep) workbench to open, which is a pain. So my plan is to motorize the window by replacing the crank handle with the motor. This is an adapter from the denso shaft to the marvin crank shaft. I also need to finish the design for an mounting bracket that will hold the motor at the correct angle, but that's a project for another day.

The OpenScad file is included so you could adjust this to other adapters. I had a lot of issues getting it to fit over the two shafts and it may be a little loose for long term use, but it seems to be consistent with how tight the window handle is. There's a fudge-factor parameter that's passed to both spline modules that will make the holes a little larger to adjust for printing variances (I hate measuring something exactly and then entering an adjusted number directly, I'd rather have the actual and show that I'm fudging it). A later revision may include a set screw on one or both ends. The Marvin shaft has a gap in the splines for one, but since the window motor will be mounted firmly to the frame, the adapter will be sandwiched.

I'm a little worried that the 3d printed splines for the window shaft aren't going to hold up. If that's the case, I'll redesign to use one of these adapters http://www.hardwaresource.com/hinges/shutter-window/truth-window-hardware/male-hex-driver-adapter-for-truth-window-operators which slides onto the splines and gives a 5/8" hex shaft to work with. I used these in my previous house with an extension pole and they worked well enough. It'll make the motor sit that much further out from the window.

author: extrememoderate

title: ZMR 250 Quadcopter Flight Controller Surround
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a surround designed to fit the stand-offs on my ZMR 250 Quadcopter frame in order to protect the electronics housed inside. There is an aperture for the USB on the one side, as well as a lower opening for the Matek PDB that extends out the side. It also has cut-outs at the top to allow easy fitting and tightening of the battery straps.

I've included the OpenSCAD design file if you'd like to make any modifications. Please bear in mind that there are multiple versions of these frames, so always worth checking that the dimensions are correct for your frame before spending a lot of time printing.

File was designed for printing with ABS support-free. I have a version of this on one of my quads at the moment.

I've always hated the incredibly uncomfortable controller of the 1985 Nintendo Entertainment System, so I thought it was time to fix that.  Starting with a USB NES controller, I measured and modeled the PCB and silicon membranes and then designed a more ergonomic controller around it.  The end result is a controller with much more comfortable buttons and D-pad to play NES games the right way (albeit on the computer since it's USB).
If you like this model and are interested in hiring me to design something for you, please check out www.cohesiveproductdevelopment.com

First, you'll have to get a USB NES controller.  Mine was a "Tomee" brand controller (I put the stock photo on the sidebar), but I believe all NES USB controllers with plastic Start/Select buttons are just rebrands of the same controller.  Also, make sure that the one you buy has only a cord coming out of the controller and not a captive strain relief as the board is a little different (I think the strain relief version was an older type).  Hopefully, most of the 3rd party NES USB controllers are the same, but let me know via comments if you buy one that has different internals.  Mine also had a QC sticker on the back of the controller covering one of the screws, if that helps.
All you will need from the USB controller is the PCB, screws, and silicon membranes, the rest is included as STL files on this page.  Don't worry if you test it and the D-Pad is a little jittery, the stock case doesn't line up with the PCB very well, so as long as it is recognized by your computer, it should be fine for this project.
I have a PP3DP UP! Plus, and as such have automatically generated support.  If your printer doesn't have some sort of removable support option, you may have to go in and add some yourself.  Otherwise, just print in whatever orientation that leaves the most complicated side facing "up" (as in, the inside of the controller will print upwards) and I recommend increasing the minimum support area value when printing the buttons as the hole on the bottom definitely cannot be filled.  Be careful when removing support from the D-Pad as the "bumps" on the bottom can greatly affect the performance of the controller if they are malformed.  Other than that, just use the photos and 3D PDF to figure out how things go together, it's not too hard to assemble.  
If you like this and want to post it elsewhere, just make sure to link back to this page.

author: Stoney

title: RunCam Swift BackPlate Replacement
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an aftermarket back-plate that I designed for use with the RunCam Swift after breaking a few too many of the housings and getting tired of paying for new ones. It works with the original bracket, you just need some M3 hardware (which you should have sitting around as it's used on most quadcopter frames). It takes two sets of M3 nuts and bolts and you'll need to loosen up the bracket slightly with a file on the slide.

Print it strong with high infill in ABS - don't worry about supports, it prints fine without them.

I've had it on my main quadcopter for about a month now and it has survived about a dozen crashes so far - one or two of them being fairly spectacular - so I'm happy to release it into the world now.

A few words on the design and process in the video at the following location: https://youtu.be/CNIZhfPRnwo

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/2pVcAskWwCE

This is like Reese's Peanut Butter Cups, I took too things and put them together for something even better!

I'm a computer contractor and I am always looking for ways to consolidate my tool collection. If I can roll up to a site and just walk in with my little netbook bag with a tablet and the right tools then I am happy. This screw driver set in an Altoids tin is compact, but rich in the bits I need.

It is a remix of a couple of really great ideas I found here starting with Zool's compact screwdriver made just a little thicker to give a little more grip to work with and still fit in the Altoids tin.

And this collection of tips is possible by Yoda2nd's Altoids 1/4 Bit Holder. I lost a full row of bits to throw in a bit holder that can be found at any hardware store. And then a few more bits to make room for the handle. Rather than reducing the handles diameter, I chose to lose one more bit.

Much thanks to Zool and Yoda2nd for the original designs!

title: DJI Mavic Pro - Spring Loaded Tablet Holder (Revised version)

description.text:
Slightly more streamlined version of another tablet holder I already have on Thingiverse,
this version has more universal holding tabs to secure different types of tablets,
also I added the holes on the main base so you can grip the RC controller a little more securely.

Use a 1/4 x 20 x 1 1/2 in socket head bolt and a 1/4 x 20 nut for the knob.

The print orientation is the same as the pictures.

The spring is a 3" tension type spring, that can be easily adjusted by stretching it, if needed,
the spring mounts between the two holes using whatever you want to use, I used some rivets I had lying around, trim as needed, I also used some CA on the pin to keep it from falling out.

title: Boiler Drain Valve Handle with 12 pt Spline

description.text:
After my 4 year old son decided to roll the water barrel across the backyard, I needed a new handle to replace the one that was shattered in the process. The boiler drain that I used at the base of the barrel (King Celcon 3/4" plastic boiler drain, from Ace Hardware) has a 0.485" 12 point spline over which the handle shaft needs to fit. Instead of using a smooth shaft and forcing it onto the plastic spline, I decided to modify MachinistMark's faucet handle to incorporate the spline. The resulting handle fits perfectly over the valve stem.

Update: Increased the diameter of the interior shaft by 5%. Old version was too tight and would damage plastic spline threads.

Warning: Do not use this on an actual hot water (boiler) drain, as the PLA is likely to soften if not melt. I'm using this in a cold water application only.

Printer Brand:

PrintrBot

Printer:

Play

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Remixed from MachinistMark's press-on outdoor faucet handle. I needed to scale it up to fit the valve spline, and then thin the center ring and grips. I used Blender to generate a 12 pt gear, which was boolean subtracted from the center ring, making it so that it seats correctly on the 0.485" diameter 12-point valve spline. Since the model was not originally generated in Blender, I exported the STL to FreeCAD in order to measure the exact diameter for the spline.

For holding a filter plate glass in front of your lens. Only changes to the original design are that it is split into two parts for the printer and the dimensions have been correctly added in TinkerCAD.

Uses 2 6mm diameter screws.

After not being able to find a Nintendo DSi stylus file anywhere on the internet that fits well and is actually usable, I decided to make my own.

I added the little nub which locks the stylus into the DSi, since that's one of the main reasons that people manage to loose the stylus in the first place.

The stylus will need some quick sanding down with fine sandpaper on the end to get rid of any sharp bits that could possibly scratch the DSi screen. I did this as a precaution since I didn't want to scratch my screen but it is clean and usable straight off the print bed.

Please leave a like on the model if it worked for you, since this is my first public thing, any feedback would be greatly appreciated!

remixed_from.author: tymm
remixed_from.title: (unfinished) Replacement Keypad for Racal Dana 2101 Counter

description.text:
These are replacement key-caps for the Dana-Racal 1992 (and related) instruments.

They slide onto generic momentary switches. I used "6x6x8.5mm" momentary switches purchased from amazon. These are similar to TE's 3-1825910-5 switch.

One issue is that the height of the caps once installed is somewhat non-uniform due to 3D printing non-uniformities. The cap doesn't bottom-out on the actuator's shaft, which I believe causes the cap to be better held in place, but creates some part-to-part variation. The installed height of the switches can be tuned by editing the "fudgeHeight" variable in the SCAD file. It's likely that you'll need to make multiple trial runs before finding the proper value for your printer's bias.

Doing this again, I'd try using "6x6x7.3" switches which have a square cap.

title: GoPro Session Mount - Quadcopter Housing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a GoPro session case/mount for the 3 or 4, used for mounting to a quadcopter. It should be printed in flexible filament and is sized as such to be a tight fit. Print at 0.2 - 0.3mm layer height and about 25% infill and it should reduce the damage from impacts to your camera.

This design has apertures for accessing the side panel on the Session and an open back so that the camera can be changed out for charging etc. without the need for multiple housings. If you keep the infill fairly low you get soft/flexible edges that act as buffers in impacts.

When I printed it I added some hook and loop to the underside and use a battery strap to secure to the quadcopter.

title: [Customizable] Basic wall mounted hook with screws

description.text:
This is a simple customizable wall mounted hook with screw holes. The design is parametric and has the following parameters:

Hook Dimensions

  • length
  • height of the wall mounted part
  • depth of the hooking area

Hole Dimensions

  • number of holes
  • diameter of the hole
  • offset to the edges of the hook
  • toggle tapering of the holes

Separate hooks

  • number of hooks
  • distance between the hooks

Round Corners

  • toggle round corners, which at the moment makes the hook 2mm thicker

If you comment, I could add more parameters.

TODO:

  • hook thickness (currently fixed to 7mm)
  • nicer shape

The included files are only examples. I just tested the custom_hook_roll.stl file. Please use the customizer to create your own hook :)

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

5 - 30%

I printed the custom_hook_roll.stl to hold a roll board, which is also shown in the pictures. The hold for this is 65mm wide, 40mm high, 23mm deep, has two 5mm tapered holes with an offset of 12mm. The board is quite heavy, why I chose 30% infill. The print took around 1,5h.

A scale model of the "amsterdammertje".
The model has been adapted to be used as a trophy for a local sport event (file: HSA_-_amsterdammertje_xy.stl). including Solidworks 2012 model. Wikipedia:
An Amsterdammertje is the typical red-brown steel traffic bollard that is used to separate the sidewalk from the street in Amsterdam. Amsterdammertje is Dutch for 'little one from Amsterdam'. The bollards have the three Saint Andrew's Crosses from the coat of arms of Amsterdam.

Printing of the trophy has been successful with 0.10mm layers in ABS. No special demands regarding Infill quantity or infill type. It can even be printed hollow.  
When printing in ABS I do advice to use a brim and a cooling fan for the top portion (with the x's).

title: Smartphone Xiamoi Redmi note 4x4 Flexible case

description.text:
Smartphone case and screen holder for xiaomi redmi note 4x

My last smartphone was stolen. so i decided do somthing for my new one after get one.

The screen holder isnt uploeaded all you need to do your own base... as all screens are diferent. but the phone holder is.

for the case. i used flexible material if i remember well... at 0.2 layer height and 3 solid walls with 0.4 nozzle and 10% infill. Used supports.
The cam protector is made with filaflex aswell.. 100% solid.

The usb hole worked perfect with 3 of my chargers. with one i had some issues to connect it was a little too big. still working. but the hole could be a bit bigger for some chargers.

In the picture ive made you can see a little rubber made with a failed filaflex print. used this cause tolerances were high made so i could use the rubber and make it move more soft also hold the parts better. works like a charm. maybe i should printed somthing for it. but i love to recicle :)

remixed_from.author: GregoryHolloway
remixed_from.title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2.1 E3D Titan Aero Upgrade

title: Additions and modifications for HyperCube Evolution

description.text:
E3D Titan Aero mount

Using a Titan Aero adds width to the X assembly and reduces X travel compared to the standard design; the amount depends on the motor and fan used. With a 20.7mm motor and 7mm fan I am limited to 295mm of travel in X with approx 1.5mm clearance either side. My frame extrusions and shafts are based on 300x300x300mm in the configuration spreadsheet. That gives an idea of how much X travel to add for anyone planning to use this extruder.

Some examples:
20.7mm motor, 10mm (stock) fan - add 3 + 5 = 8mm minimum (I would round that up to 10mm)
25mm motor, 10mm fan - add 3 + 4.3 + 5 = 12.3mm (or round up to 15mm)

E3D_TA_X_Carriage
There are two additional bosses on the back side of the carriage for threaded inserts; these are used to mount the fan duct. If you don't need a part cooler, you don't need this modified X carriage.

E3D_TA_Mount

E3D_TA_Mount_IR
I will be using the Mini Differential IR sensor (https://miscsolutions.wordpress.com/mini-height-sensor-board/) as a Z-probe. E3D_TA_Mount_IR includes the mounting holes for this.

Version 1.1 (E3D_TA_Mount_IR_1.1) adds cable support and removes the X max optical end stop.

E3D_TA_Fan_Duct_Mount
Uses two more threaded inserts to mount the fan duct.

E3D_TA_Fan_Duct
I printed this in three parts then superglued them together. For now I have omitted the top fan screw because it can contact the back of the frame.

Indicator mount

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DO9Y43uxi5g

The mount and clamp work with an 8mm diameter stem as found on the Banggood digital indicator shown in the pictures.
Indicator_Mount_1.1 adds support for the back of the indicator to stop it moving when pressing the zero button. Might only fit this model of indicator.

Indicator_Mount_Y is for checking motion in the Y direction (against the front frame).

X_Indicator_Stop

The indicator mount can be rotated 90° (thanks to the square hole pattern SCOTT_3D uses for the dowel pins) in order to test and calibrate movement in the X direction. This end stop mounts (temporarily) on XY_Stepper_Mount; I used M3x12mm screws. As you lose the X end stops when removing the extruder mount, G92 X10 can be used once the X carriage is jogged into the start position, hopefully preventing crashes.

Step-down module mount

For mounting the e_goto 24 to 12V converters from SCOTT_3D's BOM (https://www.aliexpress.com/item/DC-DC-24V-18V-to-12V-3A-Step-Down-Module-MINI-Buck-Converter-Power-Supply-Circuit/32778770850.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.G2tjiK or https://www.aliexpress.com/item/DC-DC-Step-Down-Power-Supply-Buck-Converter-3A-Fixed-Output-14V-28V-to-12V/32636205942.html). 28mm hole spacing for M4 screws.
(Inspired by https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:875468).

Spool_Holder_Clamp_Top/Bottom

I'm using this with a length of M8 threaded rod and
these https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2532403 spool holders.

Tension_O_Matic

The screws on the X carriage are good for fine-tuning belt tension, as well as squaring the X/Y axes, but this tool should help with overall tension.

Currently for 8mm X-shafts, 45mm X-shaft spacing and 11mm belt spacing. 10mm shaft version (untried, untested) here https://www.dropbox.com/s/xpcaoxigcuwk47n/Tension_O_Matic_10mm_1.1.zip?dl=0.

Changes

03/09/2017 - Added Indicator_Mount_1.1
10/09/2017 - Added X_Indicator_Stop_1.0
13/09/2017 - Added Spool_Holder_Clamp_Top/Bottom_1.0
27/09/2017 - Added Tension_O_Matic
28/09/2017 - Added Indicator_Mount_Y_1.0
04/10/2017 - Added E3D_TA_Mount_IR_1.1

This is a palette-shaped tool for measuring how much spaghetti makes a serving (or two or three or four). It might work for other small pastas, but I'm not sure. (There were some other things posted that did this, but I had trouble getting Slic3r to handle any of them.) Serving size measurements are from the plans here: http://www.freepastatoolsplans.com/Assembly_4.htm

• Print.
  • Fill appropriate hole with spaghetti.
  • Boil water.
  • Cook spaghetti.
  • Add sauce, cheese and other ingredients as desired.
  • Eat.
    • For this design, I drew it in Illustrator, exported it as a DXF with Inkscape, extruded it in OpenSCAD and printed it on a Printrbot using Pronterface and Slic3r. All source files are attached.

description.text:
While building my new UAVFutures drone build, I found that I wanted a buzzer. I found this excellent bracket for mounting, but it was just slightly too wide. Perhaps the LS-210 frame has changed over time, or tolerances are out of spec. However, I removed 2mm worth of material from the longer side to make it fit. Now it works great.

To make this, I imported leden's STL into Fusion360, created some planes along the longer side, and then broke the body into two parts. Once broken, I could pull 2mm off, and then move the two parts back together. All in all, it was pretty easy, and most of the work should go to him.

title: Flat and round Bee escape (two different designs)

description.text:
Two different models for bee escape intended for a 92mm hole. As flat as possible so it should always fit in a divider board without a need for edging. I started this design because in my opinion the factory ones are too big. Also, another goal was to have an option to switch between one- and two-way traffic, but I'm still busy working that out.

One design uses the 'vortex' approach, the other a more straightforward 'funnel' approach. Both versions have been tested and work effectively. If someone cares to compare the efficiency of the two different models and can provide valid data, please feel free to provide feedback in the comment section.

I've included the scad file so it can be slightly customized, but it isn't designed to be completely customizable, so there is no guarantee at all the different parts and pathways keep their right dimension for correct functionality.

It is designed in two pieces that click together to make printing a breeze.

Notes:

Print the top and bottom separately and then click them together.

comments.text: How does this work shouldn't the edges have an out instead of having walls.
comments.author: atka

comments.text: If the bees would have to leave through the edges the wooden board would block the exits. They enter through the top and exit through the bottom. A picture from the other side might have illustrated this better, so I've added a rendered image that shows that the bottom part is actually smaller and there are little ramps at the end of the tunnels that guide them out. I've also added an stl of the total build for a correct 3D view.
comments.author: atka

comments.text: the Vortex design doesn't seem to have the ramp.  Does it still work?
comments.author: vinnieB

comments.text: Yes, they both work. The ramp was a fun idea to create a better flow, but I didn´t know if it was necessary. Apparently not, because it also works without it. Makes sense, since the corridors are too narrow for the bees to turn around they really don´t have another option than to exit.

description.text:
Box with sliding lid designed to fit into even the narrow rooms of Ticket to Ride. Comes in several types and with several types of lids.

BOX

Outer dimensions: 10 cm deep, 7 cm wide, 4 cm tall (rounded outer corners by 4mm).
Inner dimensions: 9,7cm x 6,7cm x 3,6xm (rounded inner corners by 4mm).
Access dimensions (top of box): 9,4 x 6,4cm (rounds in at the top to ensure lid is secure)
Walls are 1,5mm which I have found to feel solid while not needing 'infill'.

The box is designed to fit into all rooms of Ticket to Ride (yes, it is smaller than the rooms and may slide around).
Will fit most size cards as well. Need to store a few cards along with some tokens (like for Game of Thrones) - use the 'gap' version to allow room for the cards on top, while keeping things separated underneath.

Recommendation: Print the boxes in a neutral color and just use different colors for the lids (or make the boxes and lids match).

Box types

  • 1 room: no separators
  • 2 rooms: one center separator
  • 2 rooms, 5mm gap : one center separator, ending 5 mm before the top (to allow larger items on top, like cards)
  • 2 rooms, 10mm wall : one center separator, ending 10 mm from the bottom (to allow larger items on top, like cards)
  • Ticket to Ride (Ttr) Europe: separator near the back to keep stations separate from the trains

LID

Dimensions: 9,85 cm deep, 6,75cm wide, 0,13 cm tall (rounded corners by 4 mm)
At a thickness of 1,3mm the lid feels robust without being a waste of filament and still slightly flexible.
Oriented the same way as the boxes, such that any 'odd behaviour' your printer has will happen the same place on both box and lid to ensure they have the best chance of fitting together.

Slides into the top of the box.

Recommendation: Print in different colors for easy identification of the content.

Lid types

  • Plain: No grooves or holes to help slide it back out (perfect for customizing)
  • Back Groove: A groove towards the back of the box
  • Center Hole: A 2cm hole in the center of the lid allowing an easy way to get the lid on and off the box.
  • Front Tap: A raised edge at the front of the box, no higher than the edges keeping the lid down.
  • Card Stand: Ten rails lightly titled, used to keep cards sorted/visible without holding them in your hand

SEPARATOR - DO NOT PRINT

If printed, this will NOT fit in the box!
Separator is included for completeness in case someone wants a box split into custom sizes:

  • Download the 1 room box and the separator
  • Use your favorit 3D design program to combine them to your hearts content =0)

author: elween07

description.text:
Triceratops means “three-horned face”. Musée d’Histoire Naturelle (Brussels, Belgium). Made with ReMake and ReCap from AutoDesk.

Triceratops is a genus of herbivorous ceratopsid dinosaur that first appeared during the late Maastrichtian stage of the late Cretaceous period, about 68 million years ago (mya) in what is now North America. It is one of the last known non-avian dinosaur genera, and became extinct in the Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event 66 million years ago. It is one of the few ceratopsians that does not have windows in the neck frill, at the back of ther skull, to make it lighter. The length of the horns and the shape of the frill vary so much from one specimen to another that some skulls have been wrongly attributed to other species.

For more updates, please follow @GeoffreyMarchal on Twitter.

If attempting dual extrusion, make sure the second head is well calibrated in relation to the first. Otherwise, the axles might not be independent of the frame and will not spin.

description.text: A simple 4:1 ratio Gearbox which prints without support material. It can be printed mono or dual extrusion. The axles have a .75mm separation from the frame so that they are free to rotate, while all the parts print as a single unit. It may be necessary to gently work the axles loose after the print is finished. Since the axles are thin I recommend printing with relatively dense infill. The frame and the axles both have 4mm mounting holes at various locations, as well as 5mm cubic insets to join components to the axle shafts.

print_settings.Notes:: You can print threadripper_full.stl, which is the PCB and the gray heat spreader in one model. There are also threadripper_top.stl and threadripper_bottom.stl. Top being the heat spreader and bottom being the PCB, making it possible to have a dual color CPU.

description.text: AMD has made a new line of high-end processors to add to their RYZEN line up - Threadripper. They were too greedy to give me a care package like everyone else - so I made my own. This is specifically a mockup of the AMD RYZEN Threadripper 1950X. This is a giant CPU. Obviously, as this is a 3D printed part, it won't work in a real motherboard, but it does give an idea as to how big the processor is and what it looks like. The measurements were based on images from (presumably) AMD comparing the size of the processor to a US 10 cent dime.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

100

Notes:

You can print threadripper_full.stl, which is the PCB and the gray heat spreader in one model. There are also threadripper_top.stl and threadripper_bottom.stl. Top being the heat spreader and bottom being the PCB, making it possible to have a dual color CPU.

Putting the processor together

If you printed threadripper_full.stl, you're done. If you printed threadripper_top.stl and threadripper_bottom.stl, you simply push the circular tabs on the bottom piece into the circular holes on the top piece. They should stick together, just make sure you have them rotated correctly or they will be off.

Designing

I designed this in 123D Design. The measurements were based on images from (presumably) AMD comparing the size of the processor to a US 10 cent dime.

comments.text: Hola, me ha gustado su modelo. Una pregunta, por donde carga la batería?
comments.author: Franrr

comments.text:
Como es muy fácil de desmontar y tiene una autonomía de más de hora y media, yo prefiero abrirlo, desconectar el terminal de la batería y conectar el cargador. Si te fijas en las fotos, la batería va soldada al terminal de alimentación de la shield del Arduino Nano, así que supongo que se puede cargar también por ahí sin desmontarlo ( sin utilizar el terminal de balance de la batería), pero no lo he probado.
Otras opciones son, cargarlo a través del USB del Nano, como se explica aquí: https://www.hackster.io/ottoplus/otto-diy-arduino-bluetooth-robot-easy-to-3dprint-33406c?ref=channel&ref_id=51222_trending___&offset=1, o modificar el diseño sacando el terminal de la bateria por el lateral y alimentarlo a través del conector de la shield.

UPDATE: Added Mr Piggy Mini (Thanks, cymon!)
I wanted my kids to have something cool to attach to their backpacks when they start up again at school. My boy loves curiousmedia's awesome Mr. Alligator, but my girl rather likes "piggies" instead. 
...and so I present to you: Mr. Piggy -- the pig you don't want to mess with. :) 
The mouth, feet, and eye are exactly the same, but the body and snout were handcrafted by your truly to make an equally menacing piggy.

There are two versions: mrpiggy.stl is the one shown in the picture with the long mouth, and Mr_Piggy_mini is the one with the shorter snout, suggested by cymon. 
1) Print (in pink if possible). 
2) Use to clip papers, bags, etc, or to scare small children.

title: Electronics Enclosure for Arduino Mega or Rambo Mini and LCD Graphic or LCD 2004 Controller

description.text:
9/9/2017
I added a vented top option for passive heat release. DD_2_TopPlateFullVented_Rev140.stl or DD_4_TopPlateFullVented_Rev140.stl
I also updated the solid top plate version to have less plastic in the middle to cut down on print time. DD_2_TopPlateFullSolid_Rev140.stl or DD_4_TopPlateFullSolid_Rev140.stl

9/7/2017
I am working on another remix to attach the raspberry Pi to the Back or Top along with the Arduino or Rambo and the LCD2004 or LCD Graphics. I am changing the front plate angle from 60 to 75 degrees to give more room on the top plate for the Pi. I also have to add a little to the height & width for a better fit. The raspberry Pi combo can now be found: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2525426

8/31/2017
I made some major changes to the openscad file to be able to adjust the angle of the Face plate. You can now adjust that in the customizer from 45 degrees to 90. If you make any changes to the code, you will have to create new STL files of affected parts. I also added a couple of images showing how the variables work for the faceplate cutouts & the electronics mount.

8/25/2017
I changed the openscad source so it will now work with thingiverse Customizer. That should make it a lot easier for others to use that are not familiar with openscad. I have deleted all of the previous versions of the files.

There are quite a few variables you can adjust. Before you get carried away & print all the parts, I would 1st print:

DD_2_TestPrints_Rev138.stl
and DD_LeftRightBrackets_Rev138.stl.

DD types have dovetail backs & the DS types have holes for mounting to frame like a Delta printer.
The brackets have the female dovetail joints that do not change, so you will not have to reprint the left bracket if the joints are too loose or too tight.

If the dovetail joints are too tight, try the DD_4. This is a test print of the Left bracket & all the joints that connect to it. You should only need to print the left bracket once since those joints do not change, only the joints that connect to them. If you have to print a 2nd test print, You can also use the left bracket you printed for your final parts.
DD_2_TestPrints_Rev138.stl .25mm tolerance
DD_4_TestPrints_Rev138.stl .4mm tolerance

Since I do not have a Rambo Mini or the graphics controller yet, this has not been completely tested yet. I tested the 2004 LCD with one I have & it lines up good. Someone tested the lining up of the graphics faceplate. The only problem reported was access to the SD card was difficult. I made that opening with an oval cutout which should make it easier now.

This project started out as a way to take the electronics from underneath my Folgertech Delta printer to mount on the outside like I was doing with just the display. When someone https://www.vicious1.com/forum/topic/mini-rambo-case/#post-39961 asked about a case for the Rambo Mini with Graphics LCD, I decided to make this project more adaptable.

This can be used with either the Arduino mega or the Rambo Mini and the Graphics LCD controller. Here is the controller this was sized for: https://shop.vicious1.com/products/full-graphic-smart-controller-big . You could also use this with other electronics that use this display if you make a base plate to mount it on.

Most of the parts use dovetail joints instead of screws. In the openscad files, you can adjust the clearance of the dovetail joints to .15, .2, .25, .3 or .4. That is the total clearance of the joints, so for .2mm it is .1mm on each of the joint. The stl files I have included us .25mm clearance. You could also add some text to that blank spot on the faceplate. There are example settings for this setup in the openscad file. There is also a test print for the face plates for checking the hole pattern if you are not sure whether your controller is this size. I have checked the 2004 LCD with one I have & it fits & someone else has checked the Graphics LCD. The only problem I heard with the Graphics LCD is the SD card was difficult to get out. I have made that hole larger with an oval outer cutout which might make it easier now.
That file for the LCD2004: TestPrint_LCD2004FacePlate_Rev138.stl
That file for the Graphics controller:TestPrint_GraphicsLCD_FacePlate_Rev138.stl

The holes for that I sized to use the electrical endcaps in this thingiverse design: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:978384

I took this Full Graphic Smart Controller case & overlaid it on my design to get the SD card cutout. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1562144

If you are happy with the test print, the parts you want to print for a stand alone case are:

DD_2_TopCoverPlate_Rev138.stl
DD_2_BackPlate_Rev138.stl
LCD2004FacePlate_Rev138.stl or GraphicsFacePlate_Rev138.stl

LCD 2004 End Caps
DD_2_LCD2004_LeftRightEndCaps_Rev138.stl

or Graphics LCD End Caps
DD_2_GraphicsLCD_LeftRightEndCaps_Rev138.stl

The electronics base plates are only 2mm thick, but adjustable to 4.5mm with openscad file.
For the Arduino electronics print:
DD_2_ArduinoMount_Rev138.stl

For the Rambo Mini electronics print:
DD_2_RamboMiniMount_Rev138.stl

If you are going to mount this case to the side of delta printer like the Folgertech or to a piece of wood, you will have to print the different brackets & back plate:
DS_LeftRightBrackets_Rev138.stl

The back plate might be difficult to use in this configuration, but included it.
DS_BackPlate_Rev138.stl

There are a lot of parts to keep straight here. Most of the variables in the openscad files are documented. If I have missed something or can explain anything better, just leave a comment.

description.text:
Glass is king

Printing on glass is boss but waiting for prints to pop off on their own takes too long and putting glass in the freezer seems silly to me. So I initially had a 120mm cooling fan on screw standoffs but my fan was plugged in all the time or I had to unplug the wall wart. All of this seemed tedious and ridiculous considering I can print whatever.

Solution

Enter glass bed cooler. Simple design that uses a microswitch to activate the fan while the glass bed is on the cooler. Once you take it off your fan is turned off as well and you can return to printing. You can view it on YouTube

Requests

Please let me know if you have any feedback as I'd love to make this community driven. Print and share your photos!

I am in the process of designing a 80mm and a 92mm adapter as well that will sit in this print so you can select whatever fan you have laying around. If you want to see another size let me know.

Fiddle

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8UboIcTWW9o

description.text: I took my reworked fpv racer 190 and stretched it out to 230. The motor holes are opened up for 2204 motors. I still need to print and test it. use the camera parts from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1120168/#files to finish your quad.

When I updated my A8 to the SkyNet firmware, I had numerous problems with the display. I tried all the fixes on line (separating the able, adding an inductor, etc.) Nothing worked.
I found out that the A6 display would work, so I ordered one.

Now I had to mount it. There is a replacement top piecce for the A8 that would mount the A6 type display but that would mean giving up the Leo_N designed upper supports that I had already installed and liked.

So I decided to design (in Solidworks - file attached) and print out an adapter.

There are inner posts to mount the new display that I drilled out (not through) and blind tapped #4-40. I used 1/4" long screws to mount the display to the adapter and some longer screws and nuts to mount the adapter to the top of the printer and the upper braces.

Notes:

The skeleton one needs support material. I gave 10% for the support material.
Holds up to 2” x 3.5” votive candle

Steps

To create I took the following steps:

  1. Created 1st cylinder
  2. Set 1st cylinder to 4” L x 3” W x 2” H
  3. Created 2nd cylinder
  4. Set 2nd cylinder to 3” L x 2.25” W x 2” H
  5. Made 2nd cylinder a hole
  6. Placed 2nd cylinder in 1st cylinder
  7. Aligned cylinders by their center points
  8. Grouped cylinders so 2nd cylinder created a hole in 1st cylinder
  9. Changed workplane to side of cylinder
  10. Created stars of varying sizes
  11. Placed stars on side of cylinder
  12. Made stars holes
  13. Grouped cylinder and stars so star-shaped holes were created in side of cylinder
    Note: Repeated steps 10-14 until cylinder was covered in stars.
  14. Created 3rd cylinder
  15. Set 3rd cylinder to 4” L x 3” W x .078” H
  16. Placed 3rd cylinder under the rest of my object and grouped together to create a base for the candle holder
  17. Created a pyramid
  18. Elongated pyramid so it has more of a pointed tip
  19. Placed pyramid in cylinder and aligned center
  20. Candle can now be pressed into point to be held in place within the candle holder

author: Nice1XD

description.text:
This is a guide to help drill the holes for my shoulder button bracket, over at sudomod
http://www.sudomod.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=38&t=3364

(please lay it flat when printing. My modeler made it stand up for some reason, it should be printed flat)
It should fit snuggily in the area above the battery compartment, wedged between the wall and the lip towards the center (please see pictures). The flat end should press against the side, with the notch indicating which direction is up. The orientation is important. Then, flip the piece around for the other button hole, making sure that the flat end is against the wall again, with the notch facing up, and the chamfered edges facing the center.
